subsection.title: Right Triangles
subsection.p: We already reviewed the idea that similar triangles have equal ratios of corresponding sides. This is at the heart of trigonometry using right triangles. An important fact from geometry is that any two triangles that have equal angles are similar. A right triangle, by definition, has one angle that is perpendicular or 90 degrees. Because the sum of angles in a triangle always add to 180 degrees, it really only takes one of the other angles to establish similarity.

We consider an acute angle \theta (less than 90 degrees). A right triangle with base angle \theta in standard position (with the base horizontal and the angle on the left) is shown in the diagram below. The legs that join at right angles are identified as being adjacent (adj) to the angle or opposite (opp) to the angle, while the side opposite the right angle is the hypotenuse (hyp).

figure.caption: An illustration of similar right triangles with base angle \theta in standard position.

image.description: Right triangle in standard position, as described in paragraph above.

subsection.p: It is sometimes useful to think of drawing special right triangles where one of the sides has unit length (length=1). When the hypotenuse has unit length, the triangle involves sine (opposite) and cosine (adjacent). When the adjacent leg has unit length, the triangle has sides with lengths given by tangent (opposite) and secant (hypotenuse). When the opposite leg has unit length, the triangle has sides with lengths given by cotangent (adjacent) and cosecant (hypotenuse). When I realized this simple fact, the naming of the proportions made much more sense.

figure.caption: Illustration of the three similar unit right triangles with angle \theta.

image.description: Unit right triangles showing the six fundamental trigonometric values.

theorem.title: Pythagorean Identities
theorem.statement:
The Pythagorean theorem states that the sum of the squares of the legs of a right triangle must equal the square of the hypotenuse. Consequently, the trigonometric values of an angle must satisfy:
(\sin \theta)^2 + (\cos \theta)^2 = 1 (\tan \theta)^2 + 1 = (\sec \theta)^2 1 + (\cot \theta)^2 = (\csc \theta)^2
theorem.proof: Consider any triangle with base angle \theta. The Pythagorean theorem guarantees \mathrm{opp}^2 + \mathrm{adj}^2 = \mathrm{hyp}^2. The first identity is found by dividing both sides of this equation by \mathrm{hyp}^2. The next two identities are found by dividing by \mathrm{adj}^2 and \mathrm{opp}^2, respectively.

subsection.title: Special Right Triangles
subsection.p: There are two right triangles that often appear in problems because they are geometrically simple. One of these is the isosceles right triangle where the base angle is exactly half of a right angle (\theta = 45^\circ). This triangle is often called a 454590 right triangle. The other simple triangle comes from dividing an equilateral triangle in half, so that the base angle is either 30^\circ or 60^\circ, and is called a 306090 right triangle.

image.description: Figure showing an isosceles 45-45-90 right triangle and a 30-60-90 right triangle formed from an equilateral triangle.

subsection.p: Once you have the triangles drawn with lengths identified, you can use the triangles to find the proportions that define the trigonometric values. I strongly discourage trying to memorize this table. Learn how the table was created, and that will reinforce the more general principles and ultimately require less mental effort to recall.

subsection.title: Examples
subsection.p: The first example illustates how you can use two known lengths for a triangle to find the trigonometric values for the angle.

statement.p: Suppose a right triangle with a base angle \theta has a base of length 3 and a height of length 5. What are the trigonometric values associated with \theta?

solution.p: Start by drawing a diagram, labeling the unknown side (the hypotenuse) with a variable, say c.

image.description: Figure showing a right triangle with legs 3 and 5 and a hypotenuse with unknown length labeled c.

subsection.p: Our second example illustrates how knowing the trigonometric values associated with an angle allow us to determine the lengths of sides. This occurs a lot in physics in the context of decomposing a force or velocity into two perpendicular components.

statement.p: A golf ball is launched at a speed of 80 and at an angle of \(40^\circ\) from the ground. What are the horizontal and vertical components of the ball's velocity?

solution.p: My preferred method of solution begins with a figure of a right triangle, where the angle \theta = 40^{\circ} is the base angle, the hypotenuse is labeled with length 80, and the legs are labeled with variables representing the horizontal velocity v_x and the vertical velocity v_y.

image.description: Figure showing a right triangle representing a velocity of 80 ft/s and unknown horizontal and vertical velocity components.
